2OCnnYmX3ItqTrOsL8KBwQ.text: Food was oK, but not outstanding. Dall was very watery and chicken tikka masala not great meat quality. We chose this place because of good reviews, but weren't impressed with the food.

jXSM1slZpIpz5onzEFc5rg.text: Very welcoming - small place where the cook still waves at your from the kitchen! Price was great for what we ordered and the taste really good also. It's a little off the beaten path which we enjoyed

OVx9rv_FCC7fv6HzafkzlA.text: Small cafe on street off Brick Lane. No hard sell. Casual. The flavors are outstanding.

Fm05MBUy9GCz5KkLnQVCsw.text: A great cafe/resto. No frills but the food is fabulous.Suggestion for two: share a Karai Gost main with sides of runner beans, red dhal, spiced new potato and one of the breads. You can always add more dishes as you go if you're hungry, greedy or just in love with the food.If you want something different but great try the sundried spinach side dish.It's not a drawback for me, but it is a little small so not the place for a huge group.Lastly the owner and staff are wonderful.

E8QXsHqzU6ACA0unjIrdHw.text: Described by the owner, Sam, as 'one pot comfort food, like we make at home,' Meraz Cafe is exactly the type of place I'd go when I'm missing my grandma's cooking. Though it's located a stone's throw away from my flat (and indeed, so close that I saw my landlord there when I went in for a meeting), I'd never before seen or heard of this delightful haven of Bengali cookery. When there, I sampled the chana masala, puri, and a cabbage and veg curry. The chana and curry were spiced similarly (with ginger, garlic, and mustard seeds - very much like home!), with a tomato and oil based sauce of medium-thickness, and no cream (!). The cabbage curry had evenly julienned slivers of carrot and onion, which allowed for a very nice distribution of different flavours and textures. Me likey. The only thing that I would have changed was that there was quite a bit of oil in the dish that pooled at the top (I suppose it was an oil-based sauce...), although that's not too different from the food we eat at home, as well. The puri was light and fluffy, but also a bit oily (puri is generally like that, which is why it's not my favourite bready thing to eat, and I always prefer chapati or naan). Lastly, the prices at Meraz Cafe are extremely fair, and even I can afford it on my student budget -- at £2-3.50 for a veggie curry dish, and anywhere from £0.75-2 for a vessel/carb (whether puri, naan, or rice), I have a feeling I will be back here over, and over, and over again. I told Sam he'd have to kick me out for coming to eat here too much, and I plan on making good on that promise.

lWgCq4M4CoT7f4cSjIDlsg.text: I must admit that I'm not exactly a connoisseur of Indian cuisine, but that being said I really love coming here. The guys are great, and the food was delicious. Even though I have a pretty low tolerance for spicy foods, I managed to somehow clean my plate! The definitely pre-cook everything and just reheat, but I feel like most of their customers aren't coming here for fine dining. My favorite part of Meraz though? The prices are so affordable. And as a student living nearby, you can't go wrong with feeling stuffed while spending less than 10 pound. Overall, it's a quick, cheap, and pretty darn good place for an easy meal.

mPUP-5XqEPp1aC8D5NqkCA.text: I debated reviewing this place because I don't want it to get crowded. This is the best Indian on brick lane - well it's actually a block off brick lane but close enough. Prices are very reasonable and no haggling. A dinner for both My wife and I average about 15 pounds total. We like chicken with special pickle and the keema naan.

yzRHHfrxxVBD08M2yD2-UA.text: Talk about cheap eats! This place is cheap and has decent Indian Food.Meraz has been around since the 1970's serving up delicious home cooked Indian food.We've eaten here many times and here are some of our favorites?Appetizers:chicken tikka: cubed chicken marinated in yogurt and spiceslamb tikka: tender cubes of lamb marinated in a blend of spicesseek kebabs: minced lamb with fresh coriander, ginger and spice (skewered in tandoor)kebab wrap: a piece of seek kebab, with a wrap of your choice (chapathi or puree)meat samosa: a dry mince with herbs and spices (deep fried)VEGETARIAN APPETIZERS ARE GOOD TOO: bannir aloo: new potatoes fried with fresh coriander and spicesdall bora: crushed red lentils with fresh herbs and spices (deep fried)pakora: a home made style onion bhajeevegetable samosa: with mashed potato and fresh herbs filling (deep fried)Entrees:Sag gosth -lamb with spinach this is currychiken tikka mossalachicken kormaIf you are vegetarian try the following:Bombay aloo: traditional spicy potatoesTarka dall: red lentils with fried garlic and red chilliChana mossala: chickpeas with herbs and spicesSag aloo: spinach with potatoesSag ponir - ponir(cheese) and spinachIf you are feeling like a Tandoori dish:Samis lamb: marinated with fresh garlic, ginger, coriander and yogurt, then cooked in tandoor and fried with onions and spices Tandoori lamb chops: marinated with meraz special spices and cooked in the tandoorLamb tikka: lamb off the bone marinated in a yoghurt blended with fresh spicesChicken or lamb shaslick: roasted green pepper, tomatoes, onions and chicken or lamb tikkaif you can't decide what to get - you can always get their Tandoori mixed grill which is a combo of four tandoori items for less than 10 quid.We usually end up getting rice and naan and we've tried the following which are all very good- Garlic Naan, Kheema naan (naan stuffed with minced lamb meat and spices) and parantha.The chicken beryani and Pillau rice are aiso very good.

lMjhJPMlduncmn4OEcFXCA.text: Visited for lunch. The dal pakoras on the menu were a surprise and delicious. Chicken kebab was good but the sweet red sauce drizzled over it was a mistake. Loved the palak and dal dishes. Service was very attentive. And the price very affordable.

2pBIFBXBjN5sd3s31oPFzg.text: Lovely place to spend your lunch time. The food is delicious and there are lots of drink options.

iB8Jc6d8WSeu4XT6Pfq_jw.text: Without a doubt the best Indian around Brick Lane, possibly London.  Looks like a hole in the wall however good example of how deceptive looks can be.  The food is authentic and delicious- highly recommend the tandori lamb chops and the dried spinach.  Great for lunch as well as dinner... and is BYOB!

jyML323mgt8oklABbDLFmQ.text: the food was ok and for london the place was affordable.  We had samosa's which were very dry.  The lamb vindaloo was good but not amazing.  The BYOB really made this place worth going to.  I would return again but with a big party of people wanting to have a good time and drink.

Dcm7vrC7QDLGl-0DbRDKHQ.text: As a visitor from the US, you hear about Brick Lane and when wandering there you don't know where to start, but after going off the beaten path I found Meraz Cafe. The fresh, sizzling dishes and reasonable prices made it worth the visit.

photos.caption: Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom

RRRVj6YCvFNCJl2sFOH43Q.text: We discovered Meraz about three years ago and it serves the best Indian food I've had outside of India! We've taken many different friends there, who have also recommended it to other friends (we should be on commission!). Samis Lamb, Chicken Achari and 'Cabbage' lamb are my favourites. We always feel welcome there with their great, relaxed service. They have no need to drag people in off the streets  their reputation goes before them!

najl8UetfmzCLMs6m8OlTA.text: Having lived on Brick Lane for years, Meraz Cafe is now the only place that I now go to for a curry! The food is always good, is very reasonably priced and we always enjoy ourselves. Unlike the bigger restaurants on the main road (where you rarely get a great meal, and are constantly pestered as you walk along Brick Lane), Meraz delivers every time! Thank you!

gtuewZA1NrfH2r8vyr3ZEA.text: The food was ok.The owner, though -- what a guy. He seems like a real pillar of the community; neighbors were coming by and saying hi and he was high fiving the kids and everything. I was sitting there witnessing this, stuffing my face with korma with a smile. I'd come back just to hang out with this guy again.

q_bZiwa_jnPXI5S8Hg3ndQ.text: This is a small shop with a few basic food dishes. The samosas are tiny, the Chicken Tikka Masala is runny and sweet :(  The Lamb Gosht wasn't bad. If you don't have Indian food often, or don't know what it's like you might enjoy this. If you know what Indian food SHOULD taste like, go elsewhere.

A54_a7qvzJ6Rb9IYmGuaew.text: Very good Indian place just a few meters of distance from Brick Lane. The restaurant is small, clean and nice. The food is really good. It takes quite a while to get your food but the reason is that everything is cooked on the spot therefore the food you get it really worth the time you wait. Prices are reasonable and the staff is friendly and helpful.

vYFIdodL99zrdODzemv3AQ.text: Great food, but terrible noise that made it impossible to have a minimal conversation. To be fair, I think we were quite unlucky to have a group of 10+ having dinner at the same time as us. I'll try to give it a second chance, because the food totally deserves it.

JEELicg-X6BJgIDuh3ROmw.text: A bit off the main road but worth it!  I had the chicken korma and really enjoyed it.  Hint- don't forget to order rice.

photos.caption: Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom. Chicken korma, chicken tikka, and naan.

DfMsGnHJFLVP5cN7tT8F5w.text: This place rocks. Few notes:- Very friendly staff- great service - food is great- extremely reasonably priced - will customize orders One thing to know: BYOB. There is a beer store right around the corner, so this is perfect.

YDZ88wi_zmj6pHOJP0id9Q.text: Probably give this 4.5 if I could but I can't. So I'm rounding up. We had a great meal and excellent service. I imagine we will be coming back.

tzony85gdKoM7aTx5EhZQA.text: I was craving Indian and London is known for having excellent options, so when we set out for dinner, we let my temporary Londoner niece lead the charge. We made our way to 'Little India' and were bombarded with amazing smells of curry. We ordered some garlic naan and the chicken tikka to start. We must have been hungry because it all disappeared quickly. The naan had just the right amount of garlic for this group.I know we shared our entrees, but can't remember exactly what we ordered. I know we had at least one order of Chicken Korma floating around and my husband ordered something with lamb. We ate every last drop of curry sauce left on the plate and were very happy we passed on all the other places we saw as we made our way here. MerazCafe was aMerazing.

photos.caption: Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Tikka
Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom. Garlic Naan

z6Idy_ZnGyqTR7shI59K5g.text: Enjoyed thoroughly, everyone there was extremely nice. Got the lamb tikka biryani which came with a side of veggie Curry and ordered a paratha. Great meal at a better price than all the spots in Brick Lane.

THwWXSN-aMp3fFU2yxbueA.text: Super good, super friendly, and clean! I think they only have like six tables. I got the saag Bhaji (which is sometimes hard to find but so good) and Chana masala, both as sides. Was under 10£ and really delicious. The Chana was a little oily would be my only negative from the entire meal. The people the work there are especially friendly and cool. Will be back

rw4o49vvvOj9WC5kK_tw7A.text: Excellent food, very nice staff. All the food I had seemed very fresh and flavorful. I liked the naan bread a lot here. Also the portions were very fine. I enjoyed the atmosphere and watching the chef add the different sauces they had for different types of flavors. I go to the Brick Lane area when in London on business for Indian, Pakistani, and Bengalese food, always something new and fun. I would recommend this cozy restaurant any day. Thanks

Ii08hHnnTPlKI8vxwC7VPA.text: Chicken Tikka masala here probably my favorite in London. A bit small size but super fresh,  tasty and has character BYOB spot,  no frills,  good service, very affordable for London : all around a solid place for both a meal alone or a night out with friends

kjJhwDn-31YAAX7Up_gm1w.text: My husband and I found this place through the reviews posted on Yelp. The Brick Lane district had been recommended to us by friends so we ended up wandering around a bit but made a turn down a side street when we saw the reviews for for Meraz. We had a delicious meal and were treated very well by the restaurant staff. Each dish was full of flavor and aroma. Small place, without the bells and whistles you may find on Brick Lane, but if you want an incredible Indian meal, give this place a try.

7sDR6PVnbmt_7TuIIGz2XA.text: Bomb food!! If you want something off busy brick lane where there's no one trying to pressure you to come in their restaurant, this is your place Food was served quick, not to mention they were delicious, nice environment and friendly staff. The only thing I wish they do was serve alcohol, but can't have everything. I recommend the mix tikka grill!

yf1F-BS1SYjfHsuhDkiBtA.text: I am visiting from the US and saw the reviews of this restaurant.  What a terrific place!  The manager was very personable and we figured out what would be best for my choices for dinner. The food was very flavorful and authentic.  The place is off the beat and path a bit and represented my favorite type of restaurant...good food, good service and good people making the experience terrific!

gZSv-Q_4lrlSQxx0tBtTww.text: Just off Brick Lane, this little café serves home cooked Indian food. The menu is awesome and has authentic options. The waiter (I think the owner) was super friendly and asked how we found out about his place - Yelp of course!!We ordered tandoori king prawns (you get 4 big meaty prawns on a sizzling skillet), and sides of chana massala and sag aloo both of which were amazing. We also had a portion of pakoras (5) and 2 poppadoms to start. Go for a mango lassi to drink...the sensation of the sweet mango and spice from the dishes is always so good!Overall the food was amazing and that was enough for two people. The only comment I'd make is that the food was really salty...we were dying of thirst for the rest of the night. It wouldn't stop me from going again though. I'd just make sure to order water with my lassi ;)

opn14I7TgL3p48N6j0WdQg.text: I wanted to avoid all the Indian restaurants that try to catch you on Brick Lane, this one is a bit on the side and not too easy to spot, but it was a great experience all around, service is good, prices are correct, there is a large choice of dishes, not too much to wait for service. If you are on a tour of London, you can use the toilets as well. I highly recommend, walk a bit more and go there if you can!

OQ_PgnuQsMX8uh1N4fCBGg.text: Food was excellent and service was even better! They were very flexible with accommodations to the meals. Definitely recommend!

9Q-8K-6tmkICwdG20N9TVg.text: Great Indian food, nice service, casual small diner.  Delicious.

XTat48Rabubx6dc9Lu8_Mw.text: We had a wonderful evening at this small Indian place with a group of 4; everybody had a different dish and all were delicious. Very attentive and friendly service. It's conveniently situated just around the corner from Brick Lane but avoiding the "hard sale" of other Brick Lane Indian restaurants. Small place but cosy atmosphere. Would definitely go there again.

aH7KkBhPvFu0F1XyDiapXg.text: Holy shit the chicken masala & chicken vendaloo were insane. The way the spice the food is amazing. Holy hell i would eat there everyday.Love so much how they puree their sauces so there isn't chunks of onion in the dish.

QvhusmmyX3bYUiymWZXqWQ.text: How do we give this place more than 5 stars? We ended up here thanks to Yelp and as others have said it's a welcome reprieve away from the clamor of Brick Lane vendors.We started with Sami Lamb appetizer, chopped up lamb with onions that tasted very good. We then shared Chicken Achari, King Prawn biryani (came with veggie side), Saag paneer (think it said Sog Ponir on menu, not sure what correct spelling is) and garlic naan. Every dish was SO good and flavorful. We had a sudden epiphany that we have been going to too many mediocre Indian lunch buffets back home and that THIS is what real, good food of this cuisine (Indian, Bangladeshi) should taste like. Seriously good - best meal of our trip to London.Add to it a clean, bright, ambiance and nice waitstaff plus very reasonable prices - wish we lived In London so we could come all the time!

photos.caption: Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom

i5_-pmidB-PxisH0bGESnQ.text: Best Indian we've ever eaten, every dish is perfectly made and practically melts in your mouth. Watch out if you can't handle spice though, or mention it! They gave my mom yoghurt to help with the spice :)Super friendly staff, a great experience! Would definitely recommend

hDQQSpWssjHz5PMBwFQ6mA.text: Our first meal in London set the bar REALLY high for the rest of the trip! We had curries, korma, naan, biriyani, kebab, samosas, and everything was absolutely delicious. The flavors were intense, with a varied level of spice between the dishes. The naan was so soft and wonderful. Although everything was very good, we all agreed that our favorite dish was the chicken korma. I could have eaten that all day! The service was spectacular, very friendly and offering great suggestions for us to try. There are TONS of restaurants in the area with similar sounding menus, but do yourself a favor and eat at Meraz!

photos.caption: Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom. Good food=happy family!

OpBEHYYl0KXrTjvYKBJqCQ.text: Tasty, quiet Indian restaurant just off the bustle of Brick Lane. The interior is crisp, clean, and modern, and the service was friendly and prompt. We were there in that odd hour between lunch and dinner and so were the only people in the place, and I'm fairly certain that the man who served us was also the chef/cook. Not being wildly hungry and not wanting to lug around leftovers, we ordered one chicken tikka masala along with a garlic naan and a pilau rice. It was the perfect amount of food for two people and we cleaned our plates. The masala was a little on the sweet side and could have been a little spicier, but overall it was a great meal. A bit on the pricy side - one curry, one naan, a side of rice and two waters cost us £20, but since the food was tasty and the ambiance nice we didn't mind.

jCuOi2qLR9TWUbILIPWXlw.text: Delicious. I was told Indian food in Bethnal Green is the food to try in London, and MerazCafe did not disappoint. I got the chicken bhuna, garlic naan and seek kebab. The kebab was ok, the rest was amazing. And the staff were lovely.

photos.caption: Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom. Garlic naan, chicken bhuna and seek kebab

QyFnC1p5o_HDjZcu5Q0gWg.text: On a rainy Tuesday the touting is not quite as extreme along Brick Lane, but I dragged my friend up the road to my secret Indian cafe ... my heart sank when I didn't recognise the old Meraz.  Luckily the decor is the only thing that changed.  Service is still just as friendly and the food just as tasty.  We opted for the daily special which today was a medium-hot chicken dish, or so they said - it was very spicy and delicious!Meraz looks less than a greasy spoon and more like a trendy soup kitchen now, they know their hipster clientele and recharging stations are added to every table - nice touch!  If I hadn't had such good company I would have written my review there and then.

photos.caption: Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom. Recharge at Meraz ...
Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom

RQd2BUmB0zXEHao_eFvvMQ.text: Best place i've eaten at in brick lane. The food is incredible. They've recently renovated their interior and its made it even better. The service is so warm and friendly!They also do Byow which is the icing on a very good cake!

photos.caption: Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom

fs_zmbWkHd-oyiT4YOYEMQ.text: I was visiting from NY and had to give Brick Lane Indian food a try... and boy, this place did not disappoint!Ordered the Chicken Tikka masala, Lamb Curry, Roti, and Tandoori jumbo Prawns. Everything was great... Prawns were a good size and cooked to perfection. The sauce of the Masala was incredibly flavorful and probably the best I've ever had. I am not a big fan of Masalas in NY since it tends to be overly buttery and lacking, but the Masala here packed a very flavorful profile punch.  It had a nice hint of sweetness while not being overly spicy. You'll see all of the neighboring restaurants in this area displaying their gimmicky banners and having their Waiters harass you to solicit business, but not this place.  It seemed to have a solid reputation and was full of locals/regulars during Thursday afternoon lunchtime.Will definitely be back the next time I am in town!

hN9S0DaoKyGlDvoN3b4A6A.text: Pricewise great! As was the service. Just good. Had chicken biryani while my girlfriend got herself a spinach dish. Very delicious

CPcblObxwL5TlqY41UadWQ.text: This restaurant was on my to-do list for a while to stop by for lunch sometime while in the Brick Lane area. I finally stopped by for lunch with not too large of an appetite so I ordered the chicken curry with pilau rice. Seeing as I was the only person in the restaurant, the service was good as far as ordering my food goes. Upon placing my order, the first thing I noticed was seeing the pilau rice go straight into the microwave. My immediate thought was, alright, understandable as business is quite slow right now, but I could already sense it wouldn't be anything in the way of exquisite. Both dishes came out, and in comparison to several other surrounding curry houses the chicken curry dish was fairly small (approximately 6-7 pieces of chicken). Overall, the taste was very mediocre; nothing to write home about. I'd recommend spending your money elsewhere for a quality tasting dish.

hqDlaCsxqlSIwBzKPB3Eag.text: Came here based on reviews from yelp. Let me just start off by saying I'm glad I followed the ratings because the food here was bomb. Went with the Sami lamb appetizer. My husband had the tandoori prawns and I had the prawn tikka. Both were very flavorful with the perfect amount of spicy. What I love about food in London is the portions are perfect (as opposed to Everything-is-bigger-in-texas portions). This restaurant is hard to find without word of mouth. It's nestled amongst tons of other restaurants that serve similar food. But it's clean (I think they recently renovated).

photos.caption: Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom. Samis lamb appetizer (FYI they have this as a main entree too)
Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom. Prawn tikka (the presentation is messed up because I took a picture of what I put on my plate but it's quite good!)
Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom. Tandoori prawns

wHWr6oavwzRMwChXNkUD3A.text: The owner was more than accommodating to our requests for special items, brought plenty of naan and even brought us a free can of beer! 100% recommend to anyone traveling through London. Great meal!

PbDaiHQBZDCTUEN1wsZRJA.text: Come here for dinner if you're looking for a great meal! I made a reservation through Google and we were seated immediately when we arrived. The ambience is casual and the place is small. It is BYOB and there are no fees for bringing in wine. We ordered a selection of appetizers which were all excellent. I would highly recommend the lamb appetizer at the top of the menu! For entrees the saag paneer was good but not excellent but we also had a lamb dish recommended by our server which was amazing. Our server and all the staff were super friendly and the overall experience was excellent!

zz0QpInhWOq8jeaLoN0fdw.text: I give this place 5 stars for food, service, and cleanliness. The place is clean and small. The host/server/owner(?) welcomed us, but not in a desperate way, unlike the hundred other Indian restaurants one street over. He seated us and made sure we were comfortable. We asked what he recommended and he thoughtfully asked what types of flavors we liked. Then he recommended a chicken special and biryani with king prawns. I've had homemade Indian food many times and this was even better. The dishes were rich in flavor, but not overwhelming or heavy. The rice and naan were perfect as well. The sauce they served with the biryani was also delicious. The host/server/owner was friendly and had a conversation with us asking where we were visiting from etc. We loved it so much, we went back the next day. They don't serve alcoholic beverages, but we saw people bring their own, which they're totally cool with. We're definitely going back the next time we're in London.

dkNCxAAS5XUzUPPHUcZHhQ.text: Very clean interior (also had USB charging outlets!?), the service was super and food was really good too. I was so happy to find this place after walking down Brick Lane and had so many restaurants offering special offers with 20% off on a meal with a free drink. This place was on a quiet street, no one offering anything but good food and service. I had paneer masala, the owner said it was a baby food - no offense, I laughed and agreed!, thought it was too sweet compared to what I had in other places, but it was good. My friend had spicy prawn curry, and THAT was really good. Their chickpea rice was good too. The owner was more proud of the prawn curry, wish I asked for his recommendations!The only downside was the owner's friends who wanted to keep talking to us while my friend and I were eating. They were friendly, but too talkative. I wanted a quiet dinner with my friend after a long tiring day.

7lTfJYp5Ac6cZBR20DkMJw.text: Super Indian restaurant, relatively cheap compared to other choices. Bear in mind that here alcool is not served, so bring your own beers or wine bottles. Great choices of curry and tandoori plates, personally I had a lamb tikka masala and some tandoori starters. In the end of the day, all of us were more than happy: good meal and good price. Choose MerazCafe if you are around Brick Lane!

photos.caption: Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom
Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom

VXH3xtds0-fJmI6-o4Xw2A.text: In area inundated with Indian restaurants this is the place you want to eat! I can't say enough good things about MerazCafe. Do not hesitate to eat here. The food and staff are amazing. I'd give it six stars if I could.

WA27JIWw6xCOF07SUPWgTw.text: It was hard to choose where to go on Brick Lane with all the many curry options and hosts beckoning and reviews blurring. I'm so glad we chose this place. A little off Brick Lane made it nice and quiet, not quite as in-your-face. And the food-the food! It was all really excellent. The curry and pakora were both really great. Tip: get something with their unique special red sauce on it. My wife got a lamb "snack" with it and it was superb. The server was also really great in a nice, distant joking kind of way. I'm not sure it's the headlining curry place on Brick Lane, but I'd be surprised if the food was any better elsewhere.

photos.caption: Photo of MerazCafe Karahi House - London, United Kingdom. Chicken korma, mango lassi, Lamb "snack"

Ou3TYz_q9FgUFIPUAkGoEQ.text: Service was friendly, ambiance was clean and modern, and they have wall chargers. But the chicken korma was way too sugary and the chickpeas were incredibly salty. The waiter offered papadum like it was free, whisked it away before we were done eating it leaving us with flakes of papadum in our hands, and then charged 3 pounds for it. My sister asked for tap water, I asked for bottled, and he brought us both bottled. Last, the portions are small. We will not be back.
